Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Advancing Membrane Bioelectrochemical Reactors For Domestic Wastewater Treatment

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET-1335930
Zhen He
University of Wisconsin - Milwaukee

Sustainable wastewater treatment should significantly clean polluted water while minimizing energy consumption, improving water reuse, and decreasing the carbon footprint. To achieve this goal, exploring new treatment technologies becomes increasingly important. This research aims to scientifically investigate a novel membrane bioelectrochemical reactor (MBER) system for sustainable wastewater treatment that integrates ultrafiltration membranes into microbial fuel cells either in the anode (submerged) or the cathode (side-stream). Such cooperation between the two technologies enables a new treatment system to simultaneously treat wastewater in an energy-efficient way, recover electric energy from organic wastes, and produce high-quality effluent that requires minimal post-treatment. The specific objectives of this GOALI project are: (1) to understand the interaction between fouling-control methods and energy production/consumption in the MBER system; (2) to investigate nitrogen removal in the two MBERs with different membrane installations; and (3) to functionally scale up the MBERs system to a transitional stage. The project will systematically compare hollow-fiber membranes with cross-flow membranes in terms of treatment performance, fouling and economical cost. It will experimentally interpret whether motional granular activated carbon can provide colony sites for electrochemically active bacteria and collect electrons during organic oxidation. It will also examine whether both nitrification and denitrification can be accomplished on the cathode of an MBER system and understand the pathways in which nitrogen is removed. The scaled MBER system will provide a new research platform to bridge fundamental research and system development and fill the knowledge gap on how to scale up a bioelectrochemical system. The project will be carried out through close collaboration with Veolia Water Solutions & Technologies, which will provide substantial support to the project through membrane materials, student training, data analysis, and other active communication/interaction. The project will also involve Pall Corporation, a leading company in membrane materials, as an unofficial collaborator that will provide guidance and help with membrane tests.

This project will provide new insights into the development and optimization of a new treatment technology through fundamental understanding of the key problems. It will also reveal the critical relationship between fouling control and energy, which will guide practical operation of the MBER system. The project will benefit the economy (wastewater business) and society (new technology for environmental sustainability) through advancing anaerobic treatment of domestic wastewater and interaction/collaboration with the water industry. The results from the research will help to improve the existing treatment process and to expand the scope of the business with cutting-edge technologies. The research findings will be integrated into current academic programs in environmental engineering to prepare future engineers/scientists for academic and industry careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sustainable wastewater treatment should clean polluted water, improve water reuse, minimize energy consumption of the treatment process with decreased carbon footprints. As a step toward this goal, this project aims to scientifically investigate the synergistic integration of membrane technologies into bioelectrochemical systems (BES) and the associated fundamental and engineering issues. Such integration would simultaneously accomplish high quality water effluent and bioenergy recovery in innovative treatment systems.

This research has greatly advanced our understanding of membrane assisted BES for wastewater treatment. Three distinct membranes have been studied for different purposes, including ultrafiltration membrane, forward osmosis (FO) membrane, and gas permeable membrane. Installation of ultrafiltration membrane in BES creates a membrane bioreactor (MBR) - like system, and this system has been examined with both experiments and mathematical modeling. In particular, several models are developed to explore the effects of operation and geometry on the system performance. The project has made significant progress in forward osmosis membrane technology by developing the first in situ method for reduction of reverse solute flux. Biological reduction method based on anaerobic ammonia oxidation (anammox) has also been demonstrated. Energy consumption by FO operation, a long time missing parameter, has been comprehensively investigated with the use fertilizer draw solutes. New methods for recovery of reverse-fluxed are reported by using electrodialysis in regular FO or osmotic MBR systems. Last, gas permeable membrane is studied to provide dissolved oxygen for cathodic oxygen reduction or cathodic anammox for enhanced biological treatment performance.

The outcomes of this project have advanced the innovative treatment concepts towards further development of practical technologies with potential benefits to the U.S. with environmental and economic significance. The research results have been broadly disseminated through scientific publications and presentations, and active interaction with the water industry. The project results in twenty four journal publications and several conference presentations. It provides ample opportunities for student training, including one PhD graduate, one MS graduate, and partial support to another two PhD students. In addition, several undergraduate students and one high school teacher (through a NSF RET program) participate in the research. Two undergraduate researchers published first-author journal papers based on the results of their studies. Both graduate and undergraduate students have developed their unique background and experience in the interdisciplinary fields of engineering, microbiology, and electrochemistry. The project has also developed new collaboration with the researchers at Virginia Tech, Southeast University in China, and Hirosaki University in Japan.
